p: Since the first report in December 2019 from Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, the novel severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) has spread quickly worldwide [ 1]. Available data indicate that the clinical course and outcome of SARS-CoV-2 are much milder than those of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV [ 2]. However, the socioeconomic consequences of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic are enormous [ 3]. The false news regarding the clinical course and fatality rates triggered a global panic epidemic which has spread even faster than the virus. Social panic has the potential to accelerate the expected health burden of the disease [ 4].
